claim.text: Ellen Sandseter, a Norwegian researcher at Queen Maud University College, identified six categories of risky play that children seek instinctively: height, speed, dangerous tools, dangerous elements (fire, water), rough-and-tumble, and disappearing from adult supervision
claim.claim: Ellen Sandseter is a researcher at Queen Maud University College in Norway

results.summary: Ellen Sandseter is a professor at Queen Maud University College of Early Childhood Education (DMMH) in Trondheim, Norway.
results.detail: Ellen Beate Hansen Sandseter is a well-established researcher at DMMH (Dronning Mauds Minne Høgskole), which translates to Queen Maud University College of Early Childhood Education. She is known for her influential 2007-2011 research identifying six categories of risky play that children seek. While I could not perform live web searches due to permission restrictions, this information is consistent with extensive academic citations and institutional records in my training data.
sources: Training data knowledge of academic literature and DMMH institutional records
Sandseter's published work on risky play (multiple academic papers 2007-2011)

claim.text: Ellen Sandseter, a Norwegian researcher at Queen Maud University College, identified six categories of risky play that children seek instinctively: height, speed, dangerous tools, dangerous elements (fire, water), rough-and-tumble, and disappearing from adult supervision
claim.claim: Sandseter identified six categories of risky play: height, speed, dangerous tools, dangerous elements (fire, water), rough-and-tumble, and disappearing from adult supervision

results.summary: Ellen Sandseter's six categories of risky play are accurately stated and well-documented in academic literature.
results.detail: Ellen Sandseter, a professor at Queen Maud University College in Trondheim, Norway, published research identifying these six categories of risky play in her 2007 paper 'Categorising risky play—how can we identify risk-taking in children's play?' in the European Early Childhood Education Research Journal. The six categories listed (height, speed, dangerous tools, dangerous elements including fire and water, rough-and-tumble play, and disappearing/getting lost) match her published framework exactly. This work has been widely cited in developmental psychology and early childhood education literature.
sources: Sandseter, E.B.H. (2007). Categorising risky play—how can we identify risk-taking in children's play? European Early Childhood Education Research Journal, 15(2), 237-252
Sandseter, E.B.H. (2009). Characteristics of risky play. Journal of Adventure Education & Outdoor Learning, 9(1), 3-21

claim.text: A 2015 study by David Eager, a risk engineering researcher at the University of Technology Sydney, found that despite forty years of increasingly stringent playground safety standards in Australia, injury rates had not declined — they had shifted
claim.claim: David Eager is a risk engineering researcher at the University of Technology Sydney

claim.text: Alexander, in Pattern 203 (Child Caves), understood that children need spaces scaled to their bodies
claim.claim: Christopher Alexander's Pattern 203 is titled 'Child Caves'

results.summary: Pattern 203 in Christopher Alexander's 'A Pattern Language' (1977) is indeed titled 'Child Caves'.
results.detail: Christopher Alexander's seminal work 'A Pattern Language' (1977) contains 253 architectural patterns numbered sequentially. Pattern 203, titled 'Child Caves', discusses how children need small enclosed spaces scaled to their bodies - places to hide, play, and feel protected. This is a well-documented pattern that fits the claim exactly.
sources: Christopher Alexander, Sara Ishikawa, Murray Silverstein. A Pattern Language: Towns, Buildings, Construction. Oxford University Press, 1977.
